headline.main: WAR'S INFLUENCE ON CREDIT IS NOTED; Ability to Absorb Higher Taxes and to Help Service Huge Debt Is Cited by Heimann

lead_paragraph: Aside from normal yardsticks used to measure extension of business credit, ability to absorb sharply higher wartime and postwar tax rates as well as to help service a large standing national debt must increasingly influence credit determinations in 1943, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men.
abstract: Surveys, US, '43: H H Heimann of Natl Credit Men's Assn
snippet: Aside from normal yardsticks used to measure extension of business credit, ability to absorb sharply higher wartime and postwar tax rates as well as to help service a large standing national debt must increasingly influence credit determinations i...
